ğŸ¶ğŸ¥ Sometimes we only need a shoulder to lean on ğŸ¥ğŸ¶ğŸŒŸ In a world that often feels overwhelming, it's heartwarming to witness the simplest gestures of support and compassion. I recently came across a video that reminded me of the power of a lending hand, or in this case, a shoulder to lean on. A sleepy puppy found solace in a trusting chick, and it got me thinking about the invaluable lessons we can learn from this adorable encounter. ğŸŒŸğŸ”‘ Lesson 1: Embrace Vulnerability and Seek Support Just like the puppy, we all experience moments of fatigue and vulnerability. It's crucial to recognize that it's okay to lean on others when we need it most. We don't have to navigate life's challenges alone. By seeking support and surrounding ourselves with a supportive network, we can find comfort, strength, and guidance. Let's celebrate vulnerability as a sign of courage and openness.ğŸ”‘ Lesson 2: Build Unlikely Connections The puppy and chick belong to different species, yet they formed an unexpected bond. This teaches us the importance of embracing diversity and connecting with those who are different from us. When we break down barriers and forge connections with people from diverse backgrounds, cultures, and perspectives, we create a more inclusive and enriched environment. Let's strive to build bridges and foster unity in all aspects of our lives.ğŸ”‘ Lesson 3: Offer a Shoulder to Lean On Just as the chick selflessly offered its shoulder to the puppy, we should extend our support to those around us. Kindness and compassion have a ripple effect, touching lives far beyond our immediate reach. By lending a listening ear, offering guidance, or simply being present, we can provide the solace that someone desperately needs. Together, we can make a difference in someone's life.ğŸ’¬ I encourage you to reflect on these invaluable lessons from the sleepy puppy and chick. Share your thoughts in the comments below and tag someone who has been a shoulder to lean on in your life. Let's spread the message of support, unity, and compassion far and wide! If this resonates with you, hit the like button, and don't forget to share this post to inspire others. Together, we can create a more connected and caring world. ğŸ’¬ğŸ‘ Hit the like button if you're with me!

More companies in India are increasing their cyber insurance coverage, reports The Economic Times. However, the cost of premiums has grown by 50-60% in the last year, industry experts say.Why have premium costs increased? This is because reinsurance companies have tightened their offerings and reduced coverage availability, says TA Ramalingam, CTO, Bajaj Allianz General Insurance.There has also been a rise in cybersecurity claims because of increasing malware attacks, data breaches, and ransomware incidents.Previously, cyber insurance policies were primarily purchased by companies in the IT, banking, and financial services sectors. However, now companies across pharmaceuticals, gaming, and manufacturing are also buying cyber insurance coverage, the report says.India is ranked sixth among the top 15 countries taking adequate cover for cyber breaches, according to a recent survey by cybersecurity solutions company Sophos. The total size of Indiaâ€™s corporate cyber insurance market is around â‚¹400 crore.Source: https://lnkd.in/gtM7SbHdâœ: Preethi RamamoorthyğŸ“·: Getty Images

Day 5 of the #drgviswanathan Challenge! Solved Leetcode Problem 9 today!The problem requires us to check whether a number is a palindrome or not.A Palindrome number is any number that remains the same when reversed. To solve this question, we can first convert the given integer into a string. Then, reverse the string by slicing it and stepping backwards (-1). Then just comparing if both the original and the reversed string are the same, gives the answer!#drgviswanathanchallenge #vitbhopal #vitbhopallions

It is time for us to acknowledge the hidden costs of customizing ERPs when better solutions are readily available.For too many years, we have seen that Enterprises have been custom building on top of their ERP systems to capture their critical business processes. It may seem logical that, since they have already spent a few million dollars on their ERP system, they build other functions, processes and workflows on top of their ERP system. Starting with the Basics - Linear Search.Linear Search is a searching algorithm sometimes also called the brute forcing method.Â Its nature is very simple. To find an element in any given sequence, list, array, etc. Linear Search starts from index zero and moves to index n (where n is the number of elements) and matches the element at that index with the target. If the element and the target are the same, then the loop is terminated. If after all the iterations, no element matches the target, we can safely say that the target is not present in the given list.#drgviswanathanchallenge #vitbhopal #vitbhopallions

Whats happening with Byju's? The following pointers capture the series of events:1. July 2022 : ToppR, White-hat junior: both laid off 500 employees2. Sept 2022 : Filed FY 21 earnings : 18 month delayed (supposed to be filed 6 months)3. The FY 21 financials showed 4500 Cr Losses (13X higher loss YoY) 4. Nov 2022 : Valuation cut internally from $22 Billion to $11 Billion5. 1.2 Billion dollars of debt was raised to ensure completion of acquisition of Aakash. However Byju's sued the lenders claiming 'acceleration of the borrowing' and also seeked disqualification of Redwood, the Key lender. 6. Feb 2023: Byjus layoffs approx 1500 employees7. April 2023: major NBFCs suspended lending to Byju's customers. This is massive as a huge number of Byju's users do depend on these loan providers given the offering range of 20k to 140k Rs8. June 2023: Deloitte resigns from the position of Byju's statutory auditor raising concerns on delay in FY 22 filing9. June 2023: 3 board of directors resigned *Before we sensationalise this series of events and talk about the one big bad , lets go deeper into the #macroeconomics changes that have happened at the same time: - #demand Changes:  Covid years inflated the demand for online education massively. Post Covid era with offline schooling back in place, the ecosystem has changed. The demand naturally has gone down, making current valuations of the company very difficult to defend- #acquisition decisions : White-hat jr 2020, Aakash and Toppr in 2021The acquisition decisions were made in a market which was TopLine focused and with that context, these decisions at that time made sense. The current market is majorly a function of Unit Economics. The market focus change now makes these very questionable decisions - The #domino Effect: Once the NBFCs cut off the lendings, Byju's had to rely on inhouse offering, Byju's Assure , Byju's Advantage and Byju's direct. Given Byju's isn't a expert into lending, this movement is making running the business both very capital intensive as well as very riskyMultiple macro factors have come to cause the sequence of events which is leading to the institute's struggle. In any outlying situation good or bad, it's very easy to romanticise a hero or a villian,  but never is the reality this simple. Both situations take a bunch of environmental factor, a group of people taking right or wrong decisions, a bucket loads of luck, good or bad. Not taking away responsibility, at this time the company needs to come clean on its financials, be realistic about its valuation, develop the omni-channel approach which its already started with Aakash. Best thing for our entire ecosystem is Byju's coming out of this a winner and thats what we should root for!  #business #byjus #events #startup #governance

Never waste a layoff. Four lessons from my experience.Layoffs in the tech industry have slowed down. But, we are not done yet. Grab, the biggest homegrown name in tech announced sizeable layoffs this week. If you are one who was affected, remember the Persian saying, â€œthis too shall passâ€.Here are four lessons I learned from my own layoff experience.First, focus on self care and what really matters, namely health, family and friends. I assume you had to deprioritise at least one of these in the quest to give your best at a fast moving company like Grab. Now is the time to set the balance right, at least a little bit. By focusing on health, family and friends you will gain both energy and joy in multiples. That will set you in the right frame of mind for the upcoming job search.Second, if your financial and immigration status allows, give yourself space and time. I recommend taking a month off where you do not kick off a job search. Take this time to recharge and reflect.I used my post layoff time to reflect on what makes me truly happy, what gives me energy, and what I am curious about. I also reflected on my lifeâ€™s priorities, and my how I was performing on those priorities. I then put some fixes in place for priorities I had been neglecting. What I reflected on are ideas that may or may not be relevant to you. Pick what you reflect on based on your context & introspection. I have found quiet reflective breaks to be very energising. I hope you do too!Third, focus on the convergence of energy and curiosity. Find at least one activity that gives you energy and you are curious about. It could be anything at all and does not have to be work related. Start doing more of that activity. If possible, start teaching / sharing more about that activity with others. In doing so, you will share energy with others who need it. Be the energy giver!Fourth, avoid getting bogged down by the question, "why me?". There is no good answer for it. Large scale layoffs are a spreadsheet exercise. They are not about you or your performance. Getting laid off sucks. It hurts in many ways. But it is also an opportunity. Donâ€™t waste it.All the best, and remember, â€œthis too shall passâ€.(Edit: my original post offered a free coaching session to those impacted, but unfortunately I have been overwhelmed with requests. Therefore pausing my offer till I finish helping those who have already reached out)

We are facing layoffs and  job insecurity issues these days. An Individual living in the fear of getting laidoff or not being able to secure his/her place in the organisation increased lack of sense of belonging, disturbed mind, Inferiority complex these days.Layoffs can indeed have adverse effects on the lives of individuals, particularly those in the middle class. When layoffs occur, it often disrupts the financial stability, well-being, and overall prospects of those affected. Let's consider some adverse effects- * Financial instability: Losing a job can result in an immediate loss of income, creating financial strain for individuals and their families. Middle-class individuals often have certain financial commitments, such as mortgage payments, car loans, and education expenses, which may become challenging to meet without a steady income. This can lead to accumulating debt, difficulty maintaining a standard of living, and even the risk of falling out of the middle class.*Reduced job prospects: During times of layoffs, the job market becomes more competitive as more people are searching for work. This can make it harder for those who have been laid off to find new employment. Individuals may find it difficult to secure a job that matches their previous income and job level, leading to a potential downward shift in their career trajectory.* Emotional and psychological impact: Losing a job can have a significant emotional toll on individuals. It can lead to feelings of stress, anxiety, depression and a loss of self-esteem. Individuals may face additional pressures due to their financial obligations, which can further exacerbate these emotional challenges. * Disruption of future plans: Individuals often have long-term plans related to savings, homeownership, education for their children, and other aspirations. Layoffs can result in a loss of progress and opportunities for personal and financial growth.* Health and well-being: Financial stress, job insecurity, and emotional distress resulting from layoffs can have adverse effects on physical and mental health. Increased stress levels can lead to a variety of health problems, including high BP, heart disease, and mental health conditions like depression and anxiety. Middle-class individuals may struggle to access healthcare services and support systems during this challenging period.Governments, organizations, and communities should implement measures to help mitigate the adverse effects of layoffs, such as unemployment benefits, job training programs, and support networks.#work #growth #job #future #mentalhealth #help #employment #layoffs #people #competition #opportunities #worklifebalance

However here's something funny I realized while connecting with them recently. Every single one of them has switched by now to another job that paid them more or equal to when they got laid off. All they did at their intermediate job was leetcode and apply. They never cared about performance at job because they were simply not going to stay there.Not to mention most of them were a nightmare to their managers. Imagine an employee who just doesn't care. Its basic human nature . You don't want ur company to be the rebound for the candidate till he gets a better job. If u have a decent budget like most of those companies did it's much better to hire someone with a lower previous compensation. Trust me a happy dumb employee is going to be deliver more value than a smart unhappy one.

And layoffs have significant, negative health effects. From Harvard Business Review: â€œBeing laid off ranks seventh among the most stressful life experiences â€” above divorce [â€¦]It takes, on average, two years to recover from the psychological trauma of losing a job [â€¦]The odds of developing a new health condition rise by 83% in the first 15 to 18 months after a layoff [â€¦]Displaced workers have twice the risk of developing depression, four times the risk of substance abuse, and six times the risk of committing violent acts including partner and child abuse. The stress induced by a layoff can even impair fetal development.â€ By exculpating the employer through minimising the seriousness of mass layoffs, we are in danger of minimising too the grave impact that layoffs can have on individuals, families, and communities. Layoffs need to be treated as such, and euphemisms only further harm the people that are effected just the same. The great shakeout in the worldâ€™s fake meat sector is happening on a large scale. Investors have sharply reduced funding while inflation has increased production costs and made consumers more selective about their food choices. Thatâ€™s hitting a crowded field, which had grown quickly after the early success of Beyond Meat and Impossible Foods.Â Â Enthusiasm for alternatives to beef and pork surged after Beyond Meatâ€™s 2019 initial public offering (IPO), and venture capitalists were willing to invest in companies that still didnâ€™t have a product. Â But sales havenâ€™t reached the once wildly optimistic projections, as high prices and odd tastes and textures have made the costly products easy for consumers to cross off their shopping lists. Many vegans also prefer natural than processed foods. The spate of failures extends from plant-based proteins and vertical farmers to insect breeders and lab-grown meats. Â The downturn has so far claimed many #startups, most of them small:U.S.: Unreal Food, Cows Gone Coconut, Sun Milk, OceanTastes, and Noops;U.K.: The Meatless Farm, Plant & Bean, and Remastered Foods; Canada: Merit Foods, Nabati Foods, and Fresh Start Â Two of the larger startups: Meatless Farms laid off staff at its headquarters while Plant & Bean got hit by soaring food and energy prices just two years after opening a mega factory in Lincolnshire.Â Industry stalwarts have also stumbled. Beyond Meat has seen its market value drop over 90% from its peak and has had multiple rounds of layoffs in the past year, as has Impossible Foods. Cuts have also affected Spainâ€™s Heura Foods and California-based Eat Just, which has continued to expand distribution in the US. Â Traditional food companies are also retrenching. Nestle SA pulled its Garden Gourmet line and Wunda pea milk from the UK because of intense competition. Meat giant JBS SA discontinued its Planterra unit after investing money into a mega factory in Colorado. Â The good news is that global demand for meat and seafood substitutes is climbing, albeit the growth rate is in the single digits. And surveys show that about two-thirds of young consumers are planning to spend more on vegan meat and dairy products in the #future citing #health perceptions and #environmental benefits such as lower greenhouse gases (#ghgemissions, #climatechange). Thus, some remain optimistic. Â The other alternative is laboratory meat. A few products have been approved for consumption, but costs are much higher than expected, and thus even if more products are approved, the #startups may never turn a profit. #technology #innovation #hype #food

I've built my career by growing SaaS startups, but my first job out of business school was at a shrinking company in a disappearing industry. Sabre served (still does, actually) the airline industry with a lot of software and data products. But the core offering was connecting travel agencies to airline inventory so that agents had real-time visibility and ability to book - which, in 2002, was no longer a proprietary advantage thanks to the Internet.Three lessons I learned in that environment:â¤ï¸ Lesson One: If your customers don't love you, you're living on borrowed time. In my first week I sat in on a meeting with a VP from a major airline (might've been Delta, I don't remember for sure). I was the data and analytics guy, so I brought the data to show that booking through Sabre would be cheaper than selling direct."I know, and I don't care," the VP replied. "You guys have had us over a barrel for decades. That's not true anymore, and I'm happy to pay more per booking to screw you guys."Since then, I've made it a priority to only market products that were worth loving from a customer perspective.ğŸ§  Lesson Two: you, not your employer, own keeping your skills and knowledge current. Because the company was shrinking, we had layoffs every November. The fresh MBAs like me were not at risk. The people at risk were the people who'd spent thirty years there. The people who'd given their heart and soul to the company. The people who had an encyclopedic knowledge of legacy systems and the two-letter codes airlines used to communicate with agencies over dedicated terminals.When you're laid off, skills like that don't even equip you to ask "Would you like fries with that."Since then, I've kept learning, working to learn from others, to jump on new technology and learn as much as I can about it. â“ Lesson Three: Optimizing for shareholder value incentives companies to be amoral - but you don't have to be a d!ck about it.In the early 2000's there was a move to deregulate the GDS industry (the industry that companies like Sabre were in, distributing airline inventory). The rationale was that airlines no longer owned any of the GDSs. Our leadership supported that deregulation, saying it would make us more competitive, and encouraged us to sign petitions, etc. Team members felt proud when our CEO testified before Congress about it, and deregulation occurred shortly after. Team members felt differently when we had layoffs and were told that deregulation was a big part of the cause. "This new deregulated environment will be more competitive", they said, "so our cost structure has to become leaner in order to keep up."D!ck move, I think you'll agree.Since then, I've...well, I've tried not to be a d!ck. I've had to do layoffs (and been laid off). I've had to fire people (and been fired). In any of those situations, you can choose to be human first. At least you can be real and not rely on talking points.

200,000 people have been laid off in tech (what I called the Patagonia vest recession). "Adjusting to the new era may be painful for people whoâ€™ve spent their entire careers employed during Silicon Valleyâ€™s boom years." A common pivot: financial firms.

In this uncertain economy, it's crucial to recognize that the job market is undergoing significant changes. Navigating these new and challenging waters requires careful planning and strategy. Make a plan and set some goals. Then, make a backup plan and new goals.  Why is being strategic in this job market so important? Over 210K individuals were laid off in tech in the past 6 months. That's not including those who've been job searching long before 2023, those just entering the workforce, and those looking for a passive job change. Job requisitions went from around a hundred applicants in the span of a few weeks to the span of mere hours. Recruiting teams have been depleted to bare bones and are running on fumes while fearing for their own job security. It is a mess.Being strategic with your job search will save you time and stress. â–¶ Networking becomes paramount in these circumstances. Build meaningful relationships with people in talent acquisition and those outside of it. Be the expert in your own career. Rather than asking someone to do the mental labor of figuring out what role best fits you, show up prepared and know your qualifications and how they align to specific roles. Read open jobs and take a hard look at your own experience from the lens of an outside party to ensure you're showcasing yourself as the best possible candidate. Reaching out to someone? Be intentional with your message.â–¶ Invest in acquiring new skills that align with the evolving demands of the job market. Take free courses, join groups, and sign up for that website that interests you. By expanding your skill set, you enhance your competitiveness and adaptability. Become the subject matter expert. These are also great topics for conversations in networking and interviewing!â–¶ Consider opening up your limitations for your next job. Narrowed search parameters mean narrowed results. Many companies are rolling back on remote policies and encouraging employees back in the office. This means that fully remote roles will be limited in number and desired by many - teams will be picky with applicants for these high-volume roles. Are there areas you can compromise? Do the research on what's open right now and consider the option that best fits you and your situation. Most importantly, be kind to yourself. Acknowledge your efforts and celebrate any small win. It'll keep you driving forward and self motivate. Your self-worth does not always equal your profession, your skills and knowledge have value. I'm rooting for you. #jobsearch #networking #recruiting #careeradvice #layoffs #resume #talentacquisition

Never waste a layoff. Four lessons from my experience.Layoffs in the tech industry have slowed down. But, we are not done yet. Grab, the biggest homegrown name in tech announced sizeable layoffs this week. If you are one who was affected, remember the Persian saying, â€œthis too shall passâ€.Here are four lessons I learned from my own layoff experience.First, focus on self care and what really matters, namely health, family and friends. I assume you had to deprioritise at least one of these in the quest to give your best at a fast moving company like Grab. Now is the time to set the balance right, at least a little bit. By focusing on health, family and friends you will gain both energy and joy in multiples. That will set you in the right frame of mind for the upcoming job search.Second, if your financial and immigration status allows, give yourself space and time. I recommend taking a month off where you do not kick off a job search. Take this time to recharge and reflect.I used my post layoff time to reflect on what makes me truly happy, what gives me energy, and what I am curious about. I also reflected on my lifeâ€™s priorities, and my how I was performing on those priorities. I then put some fixes in place for priorities I had been neglecting. What I reflected on are ideas that may or may not be relevant to you. Pick what you reflect on based on your context & introspection. I have found quiet reflective breaks to be very energising. I hope you do too!Third, focus on the convergence of energy and curiosity. Find at least one activity that gives you energy and you are curious about. It could be anything at all and does not have to be work related. Start doing more of that activity. If possible, start teaching / sharing more about that activity with others. In doing so, you will share energy with others who need it. Be the energy giver!Fourth, avoid getting bogged down by the question, "why me?". There is no good answer for it. Large scale layoffs are a spreadsheet exercise. They are not about you or your performance. Getting laid off sucks. It hurts in many ways. But it is also an opportunity. Donâ€™t waste it.All the best, and remember, â€œthis too shall passâ€.(Edit: my original post offered a free coaching session to those impacted, but unfortunately I have been overwhelmed with requests. Therefore pausing my offer till I finish helping those who have already reached out)

We are facing layoffs and  job insecurity issues these days. An Individual living in the fear of getting laidoff or not being able to secure his/her place in the organisation increased lack of sense of belonging, disturbed mind, Inferiority complex these days.Layoffs can indeed have adverse effects on the lives of individuals, particularly those in the middle class. When layoffs occur, it often disrupts the financial stability, well-being, and overall prospects of those affected. Let's consider some adverse effects- * Financial instability: Losing a job can result in an immediate loss of income, creating financial strain for individuals and their families. Middle-class individuals often have certain financial commitments, such as mortgage payments, car loans, and education expenses, which may become challenging to meet without a steady income. This can lead to accumulating debt, difficulty maintaining a standard of living, and even the risk of falling out of the middle class.*Reduced job prospects: During times of layoffs, the job market becomes more competitive as more people are searching for work. This can make it harder for those who have been laid off to find new employment. Individuals may find it difficult to secure a job that matches their previous income and job level, leading to a potential downward shift in their career trajectory.* Emotional and psychological impact: Losing a job can have a significant emotional toll on individuals. It can lead to feelings of stress, anxiety, depression and a loss of self-esteem. Individuals may face additional pressures due to their financial obligations, which can further exacerbate these emotional challenges. * Disruption of future plans: Individuals often have long-term plans related to savings, homeownership, education for their children, and other aspirations. Layoffs can result in a loss of progress and opportunities for personal and financial growth.* Health and well-being: Financial stress, job insecurity, and emotional distress resulting from layoffs can have adverse effects on physical and mental health. Increased stress levels can lead to a variety of health problems, including high BP, heart disease, and mental health conditions like depression and anxiety. Middle-class individuals may struggle to access healthcare services and support systems during this challenging period.Governments, organizations, and communities should implement measures to help mitigate the adverse effects of layoffs, such as unemployment benefits, job training programs, and support networks.#work #growth #job #future #mentalhealth #help #employment #layoffs #people #competition #opportunities #worklifebalance

From Harvard Business Review: â€œBeing laid off ranks seventh among the most stressful life experiences â€” above divorce [â€¦]It takes, on average, two years to recover from the psychological trauma of losing a job [â€¦]The odds of developing a new health condition rise by 83% in the first 15 to 18 months after a layoff [â€¦]Displaced workers have twice the risk of developing depression, four times the risk of substance abuse, and six times the risk of committing violent acts including partner and child abuse. The stress induced by a layoff can even impair fetal development.â€ By exculpating the employer through minimising the seriousness of mass layoffs, we are in danger of minimising too the grave impact that layoffs can have on individuals, families, and communities. Layoffs need to be treated as such, and euphemisms only further harm the people that are effected just the same. The great shakeout in the worldâ€™s fake meat sector is happening on a large scale. Investors have sharply reduced funding while inflation has increased production costs and made consumers more selective about their food choices. Thatâ€™s hitting a crowded field, which had grown quickly after the early success of Beyond Meat and Impossible Foods.Â Â Enthusiasm for alternatives to beef and pork surged after Beyond Meatâ€™s 2019 initial public offering (IPO), and venture capitalists were willing to invest in companies that still didnâ€™t have a product. Â But sales havenâ€™t reached the once wildly optimistic projections, as high prices and odd tastes and textures have made the costly products easy for consumers to cross off their shopping lists. Many vegans also prefer natural than processed foods. The spate of failures extends from plant-based proteins and vertical farmers to insect breeders and lab-grown meats. Â The downturn has so far claimed many #startups, most of them small:U.S.: Unreal Food, Cows Gone Coconut, Sun Milk, OceanTastes, and Noops;U.K.: The Meatless Farm, Plant & Bean, and Remastered Foods; Canada: Merit Foods, Nabati Foods, and Fresh Start Â Two of the larger startups: Meatless Farms laid off staff at its headquarters while Plant & Bean got hit by soaring food and energy prices just two years after opening a mega factory in Lincolnshire.Â Industry stalwarts have also stumbled. Beyond Meat has seen its market value drop over 90% from its peak and has had multiple rounds of layoffs in the past year, as has Impossible Foods. Cuts have also affected Spainâ€™s Heura Foods and California-based Eat Just, which has continued to expand distribution in the US. Â Traditional food companies are also retrenching. Nestle SA pulled its Garden Gourmet line and Wunda pea milk from the UK because of intense competition. Meat giant JBS SA discontinued its Planterra unit after investing money into a mega factory in Colorado. Â The good news is that global demand for meat and seafood substitutes is climbing, albeit the growth rate is in the single digits. And surveys show that about two-thirds of young consumers are planning to spend more on vegan meat and dairy products in the #future citing #health perceptions and #environmental benefits such as lower greenhouse gases (#ghgemissions, #climatechange). Thus, some remain optimistic. Â The other alternative is laboratory meat. A few products have been approved for consumption, but costs are much higher than expected, and thus even if more products are approved, the #startups may never turn a profit. #technology #innovation #hype #food

I've built my career by growing SaaS startups, but my first job out of business school was at a shrinking company in a disappearing industry. Sabre served (still does, actually) the airline industry with a lot of software and data products. But the core offering was connecting travel agencies to airline inventory so that agents had real-time visibility and ability to book - which, in 2002, was no longer a proprietary advantage thanks to the Internet.Three lessons I learned in that environment:â¤ï¸ Lesson One: If your customers don't love you, you're living on borrowed time. In my first week I sat in on a meeting with a VP from a major airline (might've been Delta, I don't remember for sure). I was the data and analytics guy, so I brought the data to show that booking through Sabre would be cheaper than selling direct."I know, and I don't care," the VP replied. "You guys have had us over a barrel for decades. That's not true anymore, and I'm happy to pay more per booking to screw you guys."Since then, I've made it a priority to only market products that were worth loving from a customer perspective.ğŸ§  Lesson Two: you, not your employer, own keeping your skills and knowledge current. Because the company was shrinking, we had layoffs every November. The fresh MBAs like me were not at risk. The people at risk were the people who'd spent thirty years there. The people who'd given their heart and soul to the company. The people who had an encyclopedic knowledge of legacy systems and the two-letter codes airlines used to communicate with agencies over dedicated terminals.When you're laid off, skills like that don't even equip you to ask "Would you like fries with that."Since then, I've kept learning, working to learn from others, to jump on new technology and learn as much as I can about it. â“ Lesson Three: Optimizing for shareholder value incentives companies to be amoral - but you don't have to be a d!ck about it.In the early 2000's there was a move to deregulate the GDS industry (the industry that companies like Sabre were in, distributing airline inventory). The rationale was that airlines no longer owned any of the GDSs. Our leadership supported that deregulation, saying it would make us more competitive, and encouraged us to sign petitions, etc. Team members felt proud when our CEO testified before Congress about it, and deregulation occurred shortly after. Team members felt differently when we had layoffs and were told that deregulation was a big part of the cause. "This new deregulated environment will be more competitive", they said, "so our cost structure has to become leaner in order to keep up."D!ck move, I think you'll agree.Since then, I've...well, I've tried not to be a d!ck. I've had to do layoffs (and been laid off). I've had to fire people (and been fired). In any of those situations, you can choose to be human first. At least you can be real and not rely on talking points.

That's not including those who've been job searching long before 2023, those just entering the workforce, and those looking for a passive job change. Job requisitions went from around a hundred applicants in the span of a few weeks to the span of mere hours. Recruiting teams have been depleted to bare bones and are running on fumes while fearing for their own job security. It is a mess.Being strategic with your job search will save you time and stress. â–¶ Networking becomes paramount in these circumstances. Build meaningful relationships with people in talent acquisition and those outside of it. Be the expert in your own career. Rather than asking someone to do the mental labor of figuring out what role best fits you, show up prepared and know your qualifications and how they align to specific roles. Read open jobs and take a hard look at your own experience from the lens of an outside party to ensure you're showcasing yourself as the best possible candidate. Reaching out to someone? I was quoted in a recent article in The American Lawyer on law firm layoffs (excerpt below).In the past months, Iâ€™ve heard from friends, former students, and other acquaintances that have been impacted by layoffs. For a profession where we are conditioned to perform (take the LSAT, get into law school, get good grades, get a summer job offer, get a job offer, pass the bar, hit your billables), it can be a traumatic experience (even if not related to performance).Layoffs, like market cycles, are often unavoidable. You are fantastic and I canâ€™t wait to see what you are going to do in your careers. â€”â€”â€”Adam Sterling, the assistant dean for executive education and revenue generation at Berkeley Law, said that most firms need to rightsize their ranks, even if their workload is improving. But that law firms, in general, tend to be reactive in managing personnel.â€œMost big firms, I think theyâ€™d say theyâ€™re busier again,â€ Sterling said. â€œBut law firms arenâ€™t great about managing their head count on a regular basis. Often, they take action in response to crises. Either thereâ€™s too much work and attorneys are complaining about how much theyâ€™re billing, or the market is slowing, and some firms are laying off people, so others say we should do it as well.â€Firmsâ€™ appetite for the best talent, which has materialized in the form of increasingly large incoming classes in recent years, further complicates the problem.â€œEspecially at a larger firm, every year they have a substantial number of people coming in that they more or less committed to them two years prior,â€ Sterling said. â€œFirms may be continuously thinking about their numbers and people coming in in the fall, and feelâ€”and should feelâ€”there is a commitment that has been made to give these people a chance to be successful at the firm. More than 374,000 tech employees have been laid off in 2022 and 2023 including many immigrants. Few people know these 6 devastating things that happen to workers on a U.S. visa:1/ Workers on visas only have 60 days from the moment they are laid to find a new job. If they don't find a new job, they need to leave the country or change status.2/ Workers on visa like H-1Bs and L-1s often have spouses who work using a dependent visa like the H-4 or L-2. When the principal immigrant is laid off, the dependent spouse loses their right to work after a grace period.3/ Layoffs potentially end an immigrant worker's green card process. The employee-sponsored green card process has many steps including PERM, certifying PERM, filing I-140, getting I-140 approval, filing I-485, & finally getting the green card. Being laid off at any stage in this process can have serious impacts to an immigrants timeline for green card & citizenship.4/ Workers on L-1 visas can not transfer their visas to another company, so they are required to find a similar role at the company that just laid them off... ğŸ˜ If that doesn't work, they have to leave the U.S.5/ Laid off workers who return to their home country and sell their U.S. assets are still required to pay state and federal taxes. They may also have other U.S. financial obligations that they'll need to resolve from their home country.6/ Workers on visas are not able to use all social services like SNAP, CHIP, SSI, TANF, wellfare, state child care, medicaid, etc even if they have been paying into these benefits for years.Here's why I share this post:(1) to inform anyone in my network of this reality so they can have empathy and (2) to ask hiring managers and HR leaders who are hiring to consider hiring more immigrants, and (3) to encourage companies to consider the immigration consequences of their HR decisions and have a more people-driven approach.

For those who are still getting on their feet afterÂ #layoffs, here is myÂ #jobsearchingÂ timeline from laid off (4 May 2023) to hired (7 June 2023) in case helpful:- W1 (over the weekend): Process emotions, share job searching on LinkedIn, ask myself what I'd like to do next, look at job listings on various portals and make a shortlist ğŸ˜¢- W2: Continue posting on LinkedIn, talking to recruiters/friends who reached out, start applying via job listing forms and referrals, do a few 1st recruiter screens, study, study, study for technical interviews (this week was hectic because my wife was working and I was looking after our kid alone) ğŸ’ª- W3: do all remaining recruiter screens, do round 1 & some round 2 technical interviews, juggle interview scheduling to keep all processes roughly aligned ğŸ”¥- W4: finish up all round 2 technical interviews, receive first offer ğŸ’°- W5: receive all remaining offers,Â #negotiateÂ compensation among 3 companies I wanted to join ğŸ’µ- W6: think real hard about which offer to accept and accept! ğŸ‰There's a lot that this timeline doesn't say, like how stressful it was to suddenly lose a job with a 1.5 year old, as the main person working in the family, and with our stay in Germany conditional on successfully finding a new job within 3 months. But the fact that I've gotten a new job (with several offers) in this economic climate in ~1 month after a layoff shouldn't be ignored. I'm no superstar engineer. I don't speak at conferences. I'm still just 7 years into my career.It is stressful, it is hard work, but bouncing back with a new job is possible, even highly probable.If you are one of those who was affected by #layoffs, take it from me: I know you'll get through it. In my layoff meeting I was told culture work would be taken on by the Talent department. this article covers the many reasons why HR should not hold DEI work.as companies think through how they plan to engage in DEI efforts, especially as the work is being threatened in this sociopolitical climate, I urge employees/individuals to look at orgs who have DEI positions or work in their HR departments with immense skepticism. HR departments protect company policies and practices not people. this snippet of the article is one of the many gems, check out the rest in the shared link below! â€œÂ While HR does comprise a DEI component, it cannot accommodate the sum of all its parts and the desired change cannot be accomplished from a siloed department. The goals and approaches of DEI too often conflict with those of HR. For example, DEI is about transparency, but HR departments are designed to err on the side of protecting the company, its brand, and its central interestâ€”profitâ€”against potential litigious backlash.â€

DEI should never be in HR. Full stop. I say this often to my clients, colleagues and students. Putting it there is counterproductive because DEI has to be embedded throughout an organization for it to be transformational. HR is designed to protect the organization using risk mitigation tactics. Itâ€™s not for the people. I love the way Amira Barger, MBA,CVA,CFRE eloquently breaks it down in this article. This sums it up:â€œThe relegation of the CDO to HR stems from an innate misunderstanding of DEI and HR. DEI is a transformation strategy, a way of being and thinking, and not merely an employee experience strategy. The work of Tema Okun and other scholars informs us that dismantling systemic inequity involves work on three levels: personal/interpersonal (how we are with ourselves and each other), institutional (policies, procedures, practices), and cultural (beliefs, values, norms). True DEI work addresses layers beyond what HR was ever meant toâ€”such as the individual growth, improving environmental conditions, fostering change management, addressing societal concerns, and facilitating anti-racism work. HR departments are dedicated to the recruitment of people for roles necessary to operations and risk mitigation.â€ #diversityandinclusion #racialequity #racialjustice #humanresources

How can firms ensure that inclusion initiatives during Pride Month lead to a lasting change for LGBTQIA+ professionals?In a Times of India article, Ajinkya Patil, a marketing strategist, says that if companies are not supporting their LGBTQIA+ employees across the year, through policies or sensitisation programmes, then they are only doing a half-baked job. A Randstad India study from January, last year, showed that only 9.5% of surveyed companies made a concerted effort to be more inclusive towards LGBTQIA+ professionals, reports Business Today. And most of such organisations were MNCs. Around 201 business leaders across different sectors, 31 LGBTQIA+ members, 10 HR/DE&I leaders, five policymakers, and five community leaders were part of the survey.Author and consultant Parmesh Shahani (he/him) Shahani says in the Times of India article that comprehensive efforts must include more hiring of queer/trans people and greater representation. The Randstad study also found that a majority of the LGBTQIA+ hiring in India is for the junior and middle levels.But a younger and more aware workforce and consumer base is driving conversations around this topic, the report adds. As India increasingly dials into 5G, the country needs at least eight million skilled professionals by 2025 to use 5G services to their full potential, reports The Economic Times, citing a report by Teamlease Services.The report, titled "India's 5G rollout: Revolutionising the People Supply Chain", states that the deployment of 5G is set to transform industrial and economic capabilities across industries, improve access to employment, and revolutionise the service industry to drive efficiency and create a better customer experience.ğŸ›œ IT and banking and financial services will be the top beneficiaries of 5G, and sectors like BFSI, education, gaming, and retail and e-commerce will also be significantly impacted.ğŸ›œ "The impending 5G rollout is expected to lead to an 80% increase in tech-related jobs," says Kartik Narayan, CEO- Staffing, Teamlease Services. Hiring for specialised roles is set to jump as telcos leverage 5G potential in network upgradation, migration, IoT/IIoT, mobility, network infrastructure, and network security, he adds.ğŸ›œ Cloud infrastructure engineers, cybersecurity and ethical hacking, and data science specialists are the top in-demand 5G skills and roles, according to the survey.ğŸ›œ Demand for roles like technical content writers, networking engineers, AI/ML professionals, UX designers, and cloud computing engineers will also see more demand, adds the report.The report also highlights the demand-supply gap in the telecom industry, which stands at 28%, and emphasises the need for industries across sectors to upskill and reskill workforces."As tech professionals, it is crucial to cultivate the necessary expertise to fully harness the immense potential of 5G," says Akanksha Shamwani, Lead - Technology and Product Marketing 5G at Jio Platforms Limited. She adds that compelling use cases for 5G encompass autonomous vehicles, smart cities, telemedicine, industrial automation, education, healthcare, manufacturing, drones, and immersive gaming experiences. Each of these use cases demands specialised skill sets, including robotics, sensor technologies, data analytics, edge computing, and cloud-based services, she says.What skills do you think will become essential for tech professionals in the age of 5G? As industries experiment with and embed artificial intelligence in their workflows and offerings, the HR tech space is also embracing this technology and its potential, reportsÂ The Economic Times.Basic AI-driven features on HCM platforms can help HR leaders improve efficiencies, increase productivity, and save time by automating basic tasks, says Chaitanya Peddi, Co-Founder, Darwinbox. He adds that advanced AI can be used to humanise experience while automating tasks. The company has integrated AI into all its modules. It provides features that aid in talent decisions like candidate search and match to identify the best talent fit, recommend the best available opportunities for jobs internally, and also predict attrition risk.AI has the potential to transform every aspect of HR â€” from recruitment to employee engagement and learning and development to talent retention, says Shweta Mohanty Roy, Head-HR at SAP India. She adds that AI-based technologies help automate and streamline administrative tasks, allowing HR professionals to focus on more strategic initiatives. Predictive analysis is another field where AI can have significant impact, says Roy.How does this impact the HR workforce? There will be a shift in skills and competencies required for HR professionals, also creating opportunities for those who need to pick up new skills and adapt to working with AI-powered HR tech platforms.Concerns around privacy of the sensitive data collected by AI software and potential biases in AI algorithms persist and need mitigation, adds the report.Source:Â https://lnkd.in/eZutAAM5âœï¸: Isha ChitnisğŸ“¸: Getty Images

As electric vehicle (EV) penetration surges in India, startups are increasingly investing in and working on charging solutions, reports MoneyControl.The three key business models that companies are adopting include operating as charging station providers like TATA Power, Jio-bp, Bolt, and Ather Energy serving as charging equipment providers like Okaya Electric Vehicles, ABB, and Delta, and operating charging software management firms like ElectricPe, TelioEV , and Numocity .Some new-age startups are embracing the energy-as-a-service model, creating a charging network and providing charging solutions to EV drivers and owners. BluSmart has invested â‚¹85 crore to set up 4,300 EV chargers, with plans to set up 43,000 chargers across 250 hubs in the next four years. EV charging station provider Statiq has installed 7,000 chargers and has plans to set up 30,000 units in the next two years. EV charging company CHARGE ZONE has set up 1,600 charging stations in 400 locations, and is looking to raise funds to set up 5,000 high-speed charging stations in the next three-five years. Exponent Energy is looking to set up 700 charging stations in the top five cities over the next year.The endeavour to improve EV infrastructure comes with its challenges. Fluctuating electric supply, high cost of charging equipment, regulations around setting up charging stations in residential areas, and lack of charger standardisation are some of the obstacles facing the space, according to KPMG.India will require around 63,000 charging stations and investments of â‚¹26,000 crore to set up charging stations over the next five years and address the surging demand, says a study by TechSci Research. The EV market in India will be a $206 billion opportunity by 2030 if India stays on track to meet its 2030 target, says a study by CEEW Centre for Energy Finance.Source:Â https://lnkd.in/grVtVCGd âœï¸: Isha ChitnisğŸ“¸: Getty Images

A bunch of companies with significant manufacturing operations in Singapore are shifting to India, reports The Economic Times.Apple, Kia, Samsung, Toshiba, Boeing, and Siemens are moving their manufacturing bases to India. In fact, a fewÂ contract manufacturers from Singapore, which support larger MNCs, have also relocated to India, the report says.Enterprise Singapore, a statutory body under the Singapore Government's Ministry of Trade and Industry, has been facilitating these relocations. Last year, the number of firms that partnered with Enterprise SG to make their forays in India increased by 40%, compared to pre-pandemic levels. Manufacturing, information and communications, and professional services were the top three sectors to which these companies belonged, the report says.What is driving this influx to India? Favourable government policies, strong economic outlook, and Covid era disruptions in supply for firms in Singapore.India is also looking to increase the GDP contribution of the manufacturing sector from 16% to 25% by 2025. These firms have made a beeline for Tamil Nadu, since the state already has 39,000 registered factories.On the other hand, Singapore is the second largest investor in India in the last two decades, and several Indian majors likeÂ Mahindra & Mahindra, Reliance Industries, the Tata Group, Infosys, and Wipro all have bases in that country, the report adds.Source: https://lnkd.in/d5-DAWb9âœï¸: Divya Pathak ğŸ“·: Getty Images#investment #singapore #manufacturing

Starting with the Basics - Linear Search.Linear Search is a searching algorithm sometimes also called the brute forcing method.Â Its nature is very simple. To find an element in any given sequence, list, array, etc. Linear Search starts from index zero and moves to index n (where n is the number of elements) and matches the element at that index with the target. If the element and the target are the same, then the loop is terminated. If after all the iterations, no element matches the target, we can safely say that the target is not present in the given list.#drgviswanathanchallenge #vitbhopal #vitbhopallions

Day 6 of the #drgviswanathan Challenge. Learnt about Lambda Functions today!Lambda Functions are used to conserve both time and space. It is used to create a function on the fly and call it, instead of defining a function, creating its body, and then calling it. To solve the Roman to Integer problem, first, we create a dictionary where we define the value of the Roman numerals. Then we use a series of replace statements to ensure that Roman numbers like IV are not written as IIII. Then we map each character from the string s to integer values in referenceTable. This mapping is made possible using a Lambda function which returns the values of the string from the referenceTable. We finish by returning the sum of all the integers obtained by the mapping.#drgviswanathanchallenge #vitbhopal #vitbhopallions

Solved Leetcode Problem 9 today!The problem requires us to check whether a number is a palindrome or not.A Palindrome number is any number that remains the same when reversed. To solve this question, we can first convert the given integer into a string. Then, reverse the string by slicing it and stepping backwards (-1). Starting with the Basics - Linear Search.Linear Search is a searching algorithm sometimes also called the brute forcing method.Â Its nature is very simple. To find an element in any given sequence, list, array, etc. Linear Search starts from index zero and moves to index n (where n is the number of elements) and matches the element at that index with the target. If the element and the target are the same, then the loop is terminated. If after all the iterations, no element matches the target, we can safely say that the target is not present in the given list.#drgviswanathanchallenge #vitbhopal #vitbhopallions

It explains that overcoming obstacles is a discipline of three critical steps: how we look at our specific problems, our attitude or approach; then the energy and creativity with which we actively break them down and turn them into opportunities; finally, the cultivation and maintenance of an inner will that allows us to handle defeat and difficulty.KEY TAKEAWAYS ğŸ‘‡ â¡ï¸Embrace emotions - When we encounter obstacles, identify how they feel and try to process those emotions. Then work to develop concrete ideas for taking the next step.â¡ï¸Be quick to listen, slow to speak - Unless the obstacle requires an immediate response, sometimes the best response is to calm our emotions, assess the situation, and formulate a plan.â¡ï¸Celebrate grit, not accomplishment - If we can learn to celebrate grit; the effort a person puts into a taskâ€”rather than the outcome, we can free ourselves with much greater certainty that it will turn out just fine.â¡ï¸Debrief after success and failure - Debriefing after failures or successes is a key tool in your arsenal to help interpret your experience and learn from them.In life, it doesnâ€™t matter what happens to you or where you came from. It matters what you do with what happens and what youâ€™ve been given. The only way youâ€™ll do something spectacular is by using it all to your advantage.Checkout the video ğŸ‘‡ to findout how to turn obstacles into opportunities!Video Credit - This is from the #socialmedia and all credit goes to the owner of the video. Most ads targeted towards Indiaâ€™s rural consumers are not likely to resonate with the audience, says an article by The Economic Times, citing a report by marketing data and analytics company Kantar.Complex ads which are heavy on metaphors do not work with rural consumers, the data shows. Hence, businesses must approach rural and urban markets differently when it comes to product positioning, the report says.Familiarity and cultural context is crucial for the rural audience, says Soumya Mohanty, MD & Chief Client Officer, South Asia, Insights Division, Kantar, citing the data. He further adds that amid economic slowdown, firms should restrain from cutting down on ad spends. Instead, they must focus on creating ads that convince the audience about their product.The study showed that short format, 15-second ads were becoming more popular, due to decreasing attention spans and reducing budget for ad spends. However, making an ad impactful within such a short duration is challenging, the report says.The study aims at helping FMCG companies decide on allocating ad spends and how they can utilise those to create impactful ads. Hey Folks,Just started the #drgviswanathan Challenge! 100 days. 100 new learnings. Starting with the Basics - Linear Search.Linear Search is a searching algorithm sometimes also called the brute forcing method.Â Its nature is very simple. To find an element in any given sequence, list, array, etc. Linear Search starts from index zero and moves to index n (where n is the number of elements) and matches the element at that index with the target. If the element and the target are the same, then the loop is terminated. If after all the iterations, no element matches the target, we can safely say that the target is not present in the given list.#drgviswanathanchallenge #vitbhopal #vitbhopallions

Are you struggling in getting response from a recruiter or hiring manager?Do you face any challenge in crafting a compelling cover letter?Sharing one-stop solution on "How to Frame a Good Cover Letter?1) How to begin writing a Cover Letter?2) What's the ideal length of a Cover Letter?3) How to structure it?4) What are the important details that should be included?If you have been looking for concise and helpful answers to these questions, this post is your one-stop solution.[1] How to begin?Round 1:(Rough Work)Start with whatever comes to your mind. Jot down your achievements, your strengths and the reasons you want that job.- It need not be in proper sentences or paragraphs.- Do not think about the beginning, middle or end. Structuring your cover letter comes later.This rough work will enable you to think freely and recollect all the important points. So, don't skip this step.Round 2:- Eliminate everything irrelevant to the job profile- Read some sample cover letters for your job profile online and keep adding what you missed out.[2] What's the ideal length of a Cover Letter?Ideally, the cover letter should be no more than a page long.- No Hiring Manager reads a cover letter that is unnecessarily long and poorly written. So, hit the target points and wrap it up strong and quickly.- Keep it focused. Do not divert your letter in a different path by adding unnecessary details like your previous job experiences or criticizing other companies.- Make it 3 to 4 paragraphs long, along with your contact details and signature.- Leave some space towards the end. Don't pack the page with too many words.[3] How to structure it?- An inviting introduction that automatically makes the reader interested in reading the cover letter further.- Solid reasons why you need the job.- Your best pitch as to why they should select you over others.- Conclude in a couple of linesThese 4 paragraphs cover everything that the recruiter is looking for. By answering the major questions: About you, WHY you and what you bring to the table, with each paragraph, you unlock your chances of getting that interview.[4] What are the important details that should be included?DateName of the receiver & CompanyAddress & Post Code1st Paragraph: Intro- The position you are applying for- briefly talk about how you would be a good fitBody Paragraphs- Your previous work experience and how it will help you scale up in your career.-Talk about what you have in mind (strategies) that could help the company hit their targets, briefly. Show how you are different from other candidates.Final paragraph: Conclusion- Do not repeat what you have already written earlier- Hint at your core strengths and express your keen interest in the positionComplete it with your signature.Like, comment & share this post so that it benefits the maximum number of people.Follow Priyank AhujaLinkedIn for Creators LinkedIn News LinkedIn News India
